Chapter 14: The Birth of the Buddha (5)

At that time, there was a Bodhisattva MahÄsattva named VibhajyavÄda-dÄna in the assembly. He had created various roots of virtue under innumerable Buddha-World-Honored-Ones. He immediately rose from his seat, came forward, and said to the Buddha:
Excellent, excellent!
World-Honored One!

Are there TathÄgatas, Arhats, Samyak-Saá¹ƒbuddhas who, in the past, future, and present, at one time, on one day, know the three past events and the three future and present events, and attain Buddhahood?ğŸ”½He replied:
He replied:ğŸ”½No, there is not.
Why is it so?
The TathÄgatas, Arhats, Samyak-Saá¹ƒbuddhas, according to their transformations, observe and see the lands, and only attain something in accordance with the needs of sentient beings.

It is just like the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, who do not take the lands to be lands, and do not take sentient beings to be sentient beings, but discern the Dharma realm and the Dharma wisdom that is born from it.

The spiritual wisdom of the TathÄgata is not worldly wisdom. Worldly wisdom is from the desire realm and form realm up to the heavens of neither perception nor non-perception, which are called worldly wisdom.
Today, the TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One has already transcended this wisdom. How does he give rise to all dharmas and become the TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One?
This is not so.
Why is it so?
The TathÄgata is thus.

As the TathÄgata is thus, so is the thusness of the world. The thusness of the nature of all dharmas, the thusness of the inconceivable, the thusness of the future, and the thusness of the number of eons in those worlds,
The number of eons of the TathÄgata is thus, non-dual thusness.
The thusness of all that exists, the thusness of the emptiness of the nature of all dharmas, is also unborn and unceasing, also without attachment or cutting off.

The names of the buddhas who appear in that eon are limitless, immeasurable, and incalculable, and one cannot see them as long or short, nor can one see them as born or extinguished. How do they give rise to all dharmas?
They are formless and invisible, not yet arisen in the future, indeterminate, and cannot be seen as determinate.

Just as formless dharmas have various different names, phrases, and tastes, so too do the collections of names, phrases, and tastes not have individual names, individual phrases, or individual tastes.
Why is it so?
All dharmas are each empty, neither good nor evil, neither with blessings nor without blessings, either with practice or without practice.

At that time, there was a bodhisattva named Inexhaustible Wisdom, who attained the suchness of the emptiness of nature and the non-existence of dharmas. He immediately rose from his seat and said to the Buddha:
I am now able to speak in front of the TathÄgata about the suchness of the emptiness of nature and the non-existence of practice and non-practice, like the Dharma of suchness.
The Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent!
Son of a great clan!
Speak as you wish.
The Bodhisattva of Infinite Wisdom said to the Buddha:
If there are good men and good women who cultivate both practice and non-practice, they will be able to fully possess all dharmas and attain perfect enlightenment.
What is practice and non-practice?
All dharmas are unborn and unceasing, without past, future, or present - this is called non-practice.
One must ultimately discern past, future, and present within all dharmas - this is called the bodhisattva's practice.

Infinite nominal bodies are not seen from beginning to end, infinite phrase bodies are not seen from beginning to end, infinite flavor bodies are not seen from beginning to end - this is called the bodhisattva's non-practice.
If good men and good women know that dharmas of the three times have arising and ceasing, and discern that within them there is nothing whatsoever - this is called the bodhisattva's practice.
At that time, Inexhaustible Wisdom again addressed the Buddha, saying:
The Dharma that is not yet complete is made complete, and the Dharma that is not yet extinguished is made extinguished - this is called the practice-less of a bodhisattva.
If there is a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva who does not see measure or non-measure in the past, future, or present, this is called the practice of a bodhisattva.
Furthermore, good men and good women!

Practicing the mind of the Way that has just arisen in the unsurpassed, true path, not taking joy or sorrow, suffering or happiness, benefit or harm, slander or praise to be sweet, this is called the practice-less of a bodhisattva.
Like the sentient beings in the trichiliocosm with a single thought and a single mind discerning the Dharma of cessation in the three times, this is called the practice of a bodhisattva.
Furthermore, good men and good women who practice diligently for immeasurable eons, wishing to hear and receive the TathÄgata's teachings, this is called the practice-less of a bodhisattva.
Furthermore, if a good man or woman practices the four kinds of equanimity, but does not boast about the four kinds of equanimity, this is called the bodhisattva's practice.
Not being defiled or stained, without past, future, or present, this is called the bodhisattva's non-practice.
If a good man or woman is neither meaningful nor meaningless, neither existent nor nonexistent, neither with an object nor without an object, this is called the bodhisattva's practice.
If one uses a pure land without attachment, and does not see the land as having anything to accomplish, this is called the bodhisattva's non-practice.
If one does not give rise to false views towards all dharmas, and does not give rise to anything, and is able to adorn oneself with inexhaustible dharmas, this is called practice.
Neither existent nor nonexistent, this is called the bodhisattva's non-practice.

Furthermore, if a good man or woman views a single land as being no different from empty space, and does not consider different lands to be attached to a single country, this is called the bodhisattva's practice.
They also see for themselves that there have been three periods of past, future, and present Buddhas and Bodhisattva-MahÄsattvas. This is called the bodhisattva's non-practice.
Furthermore, son of noble family!
If good men and good women individually discern that the realms are not their realms, the worlds are not their worlds, and existences are not their own, this is called the bodhisattva's practice.
Furthermore, son of noble family!
Discerning the three realms, practicing without practicing, not seeing creation and not seeing non-creation, this is called the bodhisattva's non-practice.
At that time, the TathÄgata asked the Bodhisattva of Infinite Wisdom:
In what kind of Dharma do you abide to speak like this?
Does non-practice arise from practice?
Does practice arise from non-practice?
How is it that you yourself speak of practice and non-practice from the TathÄgata?
The Bodhisattva of Infinite Wisdom again addressed the Buddha, saying:
Originally, I awakened by myself, and now I have just attained the fruit. I only wish that the World-Honored One would expound and proclaim it.
The Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent!
Good man!
As you have said, contemplate it well, and today the TathÄgata will expound the teaching for you.
How is it?
Son of a great clan!
When you originally gave rise to the intention to accomplish unsurpassed perfect enlightenment, was it from existence or non-existence?
He replied:
Not from existence, not from non-existence.
The Buddha said:
How is it?
Son of a great clan!
If it is not from existence or non-existence, how can one accomplish perfect enlightenment?
He replied:
Existence is as it is, and suchness is also as it is. Therefore, it is not from existence or non-existence.
The Buddha said:
Why didn't you give rise to this question earlier?
I have already explained before about having practice and not having practice.

(5) Chapter on the Root and Branches of the Bodhisattva's Necklace Sutra, Chapter 15: At that time, the World-Honored One, wishing to manifest the practices of the bodhisattvas, immediately entered the originally pure samÄdhi, causing all sentient beings to see the root and branches of all dharmas of the past, future, and present.

He also caused sentient beings to see the immeasurable worlds and buddhas of the buddhas, those who have accomplished and those who have not, from the first ground up to the tenth ground, those who are presently practicing with the body and those who are not, causing each and every sentient being to be individually distinguished.

At that time, the TathÄgata, the One Without Attachment, the Perfectly Enlightened One, wishing to deliver sentient beings, smiled and emitted a great light from his face, illuminating immeasurable worlds of the Ganges River, from the desire realm up to the heavens of neither perception nor non-perception, all seeing the light.
In that light, immeasurable roots of sentient beings were manifested.
What is the beginning and end of sentient beings?
Herein, good men and good women, by practicing one Dharma and immeasurable wisdom, can be fully endowed with purifying the Buddha-land and teaching and transforming sentient beings.
At that time, the World-Honored One told the assembly, The practices of non-attachment are as follows:
What are the practices of non-attachment?
From the initial arousal of the mind until the attainment of Buddhahood, there are fifty-four dharmas that are not attached to empty practices.
Herein, good men and good women should always contemplate this without being separated from it for a moment.
What are the fifty-four?

First, discerning the five aggregates, knowing their arising and cessation, yet those five aggregates have birth and non-birth, have noble practices and no noble practices, have empty contemplation and no empty contemplation.
If good men and good women discern the five aggregates, from what do they arise?
From what do they cease?

Form is originally unborn, yet now it is born. Understanding that form is neither existent nor nonexistent, sometimes form exists, sometimes form is fundamental. Past, future, and present form are also like this.

Form is originally nonexistent, and one does not see fundamental form. In the past, one does not see past form. In the future, one does not see future form. In the present, one does not see present form. Past form is neither present form nor future form. Future form is neither past form nor present form. Present form is neither past form nor future form. Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are able to discern and know each and every one of these.
Furthermore, good men and good women!

Discerning the dharmas of sensation, one understands that sensation arises from nowhere. Contemplating past sensation, it is originally without this sensation. One also knows that this sensation does not exist in the past. Past sensation is neither future nor present. Future sensation is neither past nor present. Present sensation is neither past nor future.
Why is it so?
The root of future pain is originally without this pain.

If good men and women contemplate present pain, it is neither past pain nor future pain, nor is it past pain, nor is it future pain. Pain also does not know pain by itself, and only then does one know that the root is originally pure and the end is originally pure.

If good men and women should further contemplate the thoughts of the five aggregates in the past, the Dharma originally has no such thoughts. The thoughts of the five aggregates in the past do not know the thoughts of the future and present, the thoughts of the future do not know the thoughts of the past and present, and the thoughts of the present do not know the thoughts of the past and future. Thoughts have no thoughts.

If good men and women distinguish the thoughts of the future in the future, the thoughts of the future do not know the thoughts of the future by themselves, the thoughts of the future do not know the thoughts of the past and present, the thoughts of the future and past do not know the future, the thoughts of the past do not know the thoughts of the future and present.

If good sons and good women, in the present, discern past thoughts but there are no past thoughts, discern future thoughts but there are no future thoughts, discern present thoughts but there are no present thoughts, in the present and past there are no past thoughts, in the present and future there are no present future thoughts, and in present thoughts there are no thoughts.
If good sons and good women, moreover, should in the past discern the five aggregates, from what are they born?
From what do they cease?

Past actions are also not existent actions, discerning past actions are not past actions, past actions are not future actions or present actions, future actions are not past actions or present actions, present actions are not past actions or future actions, past future actions are not past future actions, past present actions are not past present actions.
Why is it so?
The basis of practice is originally non-existent and does not exist as practice.

If good sons and good women, in the future, will be fully endowed with future practices, in the future they will not see past practices, nor will they see present practices. In the future, they will not see future past practices, nor will they see future present practices, nor will they see future present practices.
Why is this?
Originally, there are no such practices.
If good sons and good women, in the present, should further discern, past practices are also without past practices, and also without future practices and also without present practices.

In present practices, contemplating present past practices, also not seeing present past practices, in the present contemplating present future practices, also not seeing present future practices, contemplating all practices are all non-existent.

If good sons and good women contemplate past consciousness in the past, they also do not see past consciousness. In future consciousness, they also do not see future consciousness. In present consciousness, they also do not see present consciousness. In past consciousness, they also do not see past and future consciousness. In the past, they also do not see past and present consciousness, nor do they see consciousness.ğŸ”½If good sons and good women do not see past consciousness and future consciousness in the future, in the future they do not see future and past consciousness, nor do they see future and present consciousness.

If good sons and good women do not see past consciousness or future consciousness in present consciousness, in the present they do not see present and past consciousness, nor do they see present and future consciousness. This is what is meant by good sons and good women discerning the emptiness of the beginning and end of the five aggregates.
Chapter 16: Not Consciousness, Not Non-Consciousness (5) Bodhisattva Necklace Sutra, Chapter 16: Not Consciousness, Not Non-Consciousness At that time, Bodhisattva Form Echo said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
I have just heard the TathÄgata, the Worthy of Offerings, the Perfectly Enlightened One, speak of the fundamental nature of sentient beings.
Today I wish to rely on the TathÄgata's majestic spiritual power to speak of consciousness and non-consciousness.
I only pray, World-Honored One!
If you listen, I will dare to speak.
The Buddha said:
Son of a great clan!
If you enjoy speaking, then speak.
Bodhisattva Form Echo then praised the Buddha in verse in front of the Buddha:
The World-Honored One greatly proclaims the vow, knowing the fundamental nature of sentient beings,
Today I have already obtained permission to speak the teachings from the spiritual honored one's mouth.
Originally, from countless Buddhas, I have always sought to hear this essential teaching,
Now hearing the teachings of the holy honored one, I listen to speak of the teachings of existence and non-existence.
In the past, for countless eons, I served the holy ones,
Just as I have now attained, with the foremost eloquence of sound and resonance.
Form also has no form, and one does not see existence or non-existence,
Without dust, without defilements, now called the Honored One among Humans.
Human birth is originally unborn, how much more so do I have birth?
Because I have no intention of birth, I wish to speak of the basis of lesser wisdom,
Not daring with foolish thoughts, to proclaim the teachings of the TathÄgata.
Remembering my own past practices, I only listen without daring to doubt,
Birth and death are immeasurable, receiving one body after another,
Until the end, harboring doubts, I only listen to the unfolding of it.
At that time, after Bodhisattva Form and Resonance spoke these verses, he addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
Understanding the supreme truth without distinguishing this consciousness from that consciousness, this is called having consciousness and not having consciousness.

Not seeing the grasping of existence or the grasping of non-existence, all dharmas are of one mark, all non-existent and all existent - this is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's having consciousness and not having consciousness.

Discerning the various types, this is pure consciousness, this is impure consciousness, I have accomplished the excellent marks, they have not accomplished the excellent marks, all able to observe and understand, but non-existent - this is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's having consciousness and not having consciousness.

Discerning the time and seeing the buddhas, in this eon there is a buddha, in that eon there is no buddha, not rejoicing because there is a buddha, and even if there is no buddha, also not depressed - this is called the bodhisattva's having consciousness and not having consciousness.

I further observe the various types of sentient beings, those with skillful means and those without skillful means, not giving rise to thoughts or practices in between - this is called the bodhisattva's having consciousness and not having consciousness.

Furthermore, observing sentient beings, knowing their lifespan limits, some sentient beings should be liberated from the previous eon, some sentient beings should be liberated from the later eon, some sentient beings should be liberated from the present eon, and also not seeing this eon as having liberation or not having liberation, this is called the bodhisattva having consciousness and not having consciousness.
At that time, there was a bodhisattva named SamantaprabhÄsa who immediately rose from his seat, came forward, and said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
I am also able to speak of having consciousness and not having consciousness in the presence of the TathÄgata.
He further spoke in verse, saying:
In the buddhas as numerous as the sands of the Ganges, creating this multitude of meritorious deeds,
The mind contemplates the perfect enlightenment, accumulating practices and being conscious of past lives.
Not attached to self, person, or longevity, birth and death have no root,
The characteristics of the path have no form or sign, now encountering the Honored One among humans.
The wisdom of equality in the three times, neither consciousness nor non-consciousness,
Destroying karmic activity and not creating new karma, then bestowing predictions on disciples.
One consciousness is also not one, awakening to the profound essentials of the Dharma,
Transcending the buddha-lands, the immeasurable buddha-realms.
Originally, from countless eons, hearing the teachings one attains awakening,
Wishing to listen to the explanation of consciousness and non-consciousness in the presence of the TathÄgata.
Discerning the profound and wondrous Dharma, now encountering the Honored One among humans,
Fully penetrating the realm of nirvÄá¹‡a, only wishing to listen to the explanation.
At that time, the bodhisattva Complete with Various Marks said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!

As I am called Complete with Various Marks today, the arising of marks does not know the arising of marks, the cessation of marks does not know the cessation of marks, this is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva having consciousness and no consciousness.
The bodhisattva Complete with Various Marks said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!

As I recall, I heard this essential teaching from the TathÄgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One of Wisdom and Awareness in the past. All sentient beings, from the initial arousal of the mind until the attainment of Buddhahood, do not see the characteristics of consciousness. This is called the consciousness of the bodhisattva that is both existent and non-existent.

If good men and good women individually discern the six deteriorations and six entrances, knowing that past deteriorations are not past deteriorations, knowing that future deteriorations are not future deteriorations, and knowing that present deteriorations are not present deteriorations, and do not give rise to attachment to thoughts within them, this is called the consciousness that is both existent and non-existent.
The bodhisattva born of the lineage said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!

Today, in the presence of the TathÄgata, I heard Sound-Vibration Bodhisattva speak of the consciousness that is both existent and non-existent, and I also heard Multitude-Characteristics Bodhisattva speak of the consciousness that is both existent and non-existent.
What is it?
World-Honored One!
What is meant by consciousness? What is consciousness?
The Buddha said:
It is like emptiness.
The bodhisattva born of the lineage said to the Buddha again:
World-Honored One!
How is it like empty space?
The Buddha said:
Non-arising, non-ceasing, non-attachment, and non-cutting off.
The Bodhisattva of the Lineage asked the Buddha, saying:
Now I ask the TathÄgata about the arising of consciousness, but you answer me with emptiness?
The Buddha said:
Not so.
I now say that consciousness is neither existent nor non-existent, and therefore it is called both existent and non-existent consciousness.
The Bodhisattva of the Lineage said:
Is consciousness with characteristics or without characteristics?
The Buddha said:
Consciousness is neither with characteristics nor without characteristics.
The Bodhisattva of the Lineage said to the Buddha:
How is it that consciousness is neither with characteristics nor without characteristics?
The Buddha said:ğŸ”½Originally it is not with characteristics, nor is it with characteristics now, and therefore the original consciousness is not the present consciousness;
The present consciousness is not the original consciousness, and therefore consciousness is neither with characteristics nor without characteristics.
At that time, the Bodhisattva Born from a Good Family said to the Buddha:
If existence has characteristics and is not consciousness, and non-existence has no characteristics and is not consciousness, why is it said that consciousness cognizes?
The Buddha said:
It follows the arising of consciousness.
When consciousness arises, it arises; when consciousness ceases, it ceases. Therefore, it is neither with characteristics nor without characteristics.
The Buddha further told the son of a good family:
What do you think?
Bodhisattva Born from a Good Family!
Do you now have consciousness or not?
He replied:
No, there is not.ğŸ”½ğŸ”½
Why is it so?
It has no form and no appearance, it is not present, not past, and not future.
The Buddha said:
You have already said that consciousness has no consciousness, it is not present, not future, and not past. Whose words are you speaking now?
He replied:
Do you want to say it is consciousness?
Or is it the one born from a good family?
The Buddha said:
I do not ask about the consciousness of a bodhisattva taking birth, but rather about whether consciousness exists or not.
He replied:
Consciousness is neither existent nor non-existent.
The Buddha said:
It is so, it is so.
Son of good family!
At that time, the Bodhisattva Born of Lineage addressed the Buddha, saying:
How is it?
World-Honored One!
Today, the Tathagata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, does he speak of existence or non-existence based on consciousness?
Or does he not speak of existence or non-existence based on consciousness?
The Buddha said:
What meaning do you have in mind when you ask the Tathagata?
The Bodhisattva Born of Lineage addressed the Buddha, saying:
Earlier, the Tathagata asked:
'Do you now speak of the existence or non-existence of consciousness?
Is there a future, present, or past?
Or is there no future, present, or past?'
I replied:
'No, World-Honored One!
Just as the World-Honored One says, there is no present, future, or past consciousness.
Where is my consciousness and the TathÄgata's consciousness?
The Buddha said:

I have already said before that consciousness is neither existent nor non-existent. It is only the TathÄgata, the Worthy One, the Perfectly Enlightened One, who uses various dharmas to awaken sentient beings.
What do you think?
Son of a great clan!
If good sons and good women understand this dharma, they will be able to fully possess all dharmas.
At that time, there was a bodhisattva named Powerful, who immediately rose from his seat and said to the Buddha:
I am also able to speak of the existence and non-existence of consciousness.
The bodhisattva Powerful then spoke a verse in front of the Buddha, saying:
I have heard from the Honored One of the Ten Powers about this existence and non-existence of consciousness,
The eightfold noble path, expounding unobstructed wisdom.
The sounds are each different, the realms of sentient beings are not the same,
Generously giving without any thought of equality, called the ten powers.
If I attain Buddhahood in the future, I will discern the Dharma realm,
From a single practice without duality, I only wish to listen to the explanation of consciousness.
The Way originally arises from me, due to my non-arising of consciousness,
Calculating, there is no thought, neither existent consciousness nor non-existent consciousness.
Accumulating from small to great practice, one then attains enlightenment by oneself,
Birth and death cannot be measured, how can the divine consciousness be exhausted?
I now rely on the honored spirit, with few desires I explain by myself,
I only wish to be in the presence of the sage, to approach the storehouse of all Buddhas.
At that time, after Power-Flourishing Bodhisattva spoke these verses, he addressed the Buddha, saying:
What is it?
World-Honored One!
If one discerns the TathÄgata's ten powers as indestructible, how are the TathÄgata's ten powers indestructible?
First, the TathÄgata's intention to seek unsurpassed perfect enlightenment is indestructible. This is called the bodhisattva's consciousness and non-consciousness.
Moreover, knowing the combination of this and that without seeing the beginning and end, this is called the bodhisattva's consciousness and non-consciousness.

Observing the fundamental practice of sentient beings, understanding their naturalness, and then knowing the immeasurable origins from which they come, this is called the bodhisattva's consciousness and non-consciousness.

All dharmas originally have no form. Accumulated due to delusion, this consciousness arises. Distinguishing this delusion without knowing its origin and cessation, this is called the bodhisattva's consciousness and non-consciousness.

Distinguishing the various knowledges, there are three fundamental practices. From having understanding, one falls back into the four inverted views. Within the four inverted views, understanding them to be illusory transformations, not seeing inversion, and not seeing non-inversion, this is called the bodhisattva's consciousness and non-consciousness.
Moreover, regarding the four matters, observing the fundamental completeness of sentient beings' five practices, one is able to contemplate and immediately accomplish the five matters.
If good sons and good women, in the originally non-existent practice, practice without traces of practice.
What are the five?
First, mindfulness;
second, turning mindfulness;
third, basis;
fourth, delusion;
fifth, inexhaustibility. These are called the consciousness and non-consciousness of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas.

There is also an inconceivable Dharma of consciousness, with skillful means that cannot be measured by ordinary people. There are four practices. Seeing the arising and cessation of various buddha-lands, one is then able to accomplish the non-seeing of arising and cessation. This is called the consciousness and non-consciousness of bodhisattvas.
The TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One, observes the past, future, and present, and also does not see the fundamental past, future, and present.

If one is born in the five destinies and receives the form of sentient beings in the five destinies, one can discriminate the five destinies and follow their entry. One is further able to discriminate the reception of form with faculties and form without faculties.

If a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva has already received the heavenly faculties but not the dragon faculties, although he wishes to receive the dragon faculties, he is still able to bring down the Dharma rain.

If a good son or good woman obtains the rÄká¹£asa faculties, leaves the rÄká¹£asa faculties, and receives the asura faculties, he will be able to be fully endowed with consciousness and unconsciousness.
Abandoning those asura faculties, he receives the gandharva faculties, and having abandoned those faculties, he is able to be fully endowed with consciousness and unconsciousness.
The same is true for caá¹‡á¸Älas, mÄras, kiá¹ƒnaras, humans, and non-humans. This is called the inconceivable Dharma treasury that the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva penetrates.

Chapter 17: Immeasurable (5) Bodhisattva Ornament Sutra, Chapter 17: Immeasurable Furthermore, good men and good women, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also able to fully know that the teachings established by the buddhas have definite quantity and immeasurable quantity.
How is it so?
Son of a great clan!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas and all buddhas enter this samÄdhi and exhaustively know the teachings established by all buddhas, whether they are limited or unlimited. They are able to exhaustively know the verbal actions, bodily actions, and mental actions spoken by all buddhas.

In this way, sons and daughters of good family!

They are then able to fully understand the TathÄgata's teachings, able to make what is not a realm have the conception of a realm, able to make what is a realm have the conception of not a realm, and in that world, speak of the Dharma of one contemplation. This is called the good men and good women accomplishing one of the eighteen wisdoms.

Foreseeing countless events in the future, and knowing the Buddhas of the past, present, and future, whether or not they are Buddhas, whether or not they are Bodhisattvas, this is called the Bodhisattva accomplishing the second of the eighteen wisdoms.
Furthermore, good men and good women!

The past is immeasurable, without conditions, and countless, ending without seeing an end, arising without seeing an arising. This is called the Bodhisattva accomplishing the third of the eighteen wisdoms.
Furthermore, good men and good women!

Internally and externally distinguishing the four impermanent practices, in the middle, observing one's own bodily practices as being complete, this is called the Bodhisattva accomplishing the fourth of the eighteen wisdoms.
Furthermore, good men and good women,

the Buddha realm is immeasurable and inconceivable, and one is able to discern that the two matters of the buddhas, delusion and desire, are all known to be of the nature of emptiness. This is called the good men and good women accomplishing the fifth dharma among the eighteen kinds of wisdom-illumination.
Furthermore, good men and good women,

if one is able to contemplate the emptiness of the internal and external one by one, that I do not belong to them and they do not belong to me, and to know one by one that they are empty and tranquil and do not exist, this is called the good men and good women accomplishing the sixth dharma among the eighteen dharmas.
Furthermore, sons and daughters of good family,

space is without characteristics and cannot be made to have characteristics by space. To discern one's body within as being equal to that empty space, this is called the good men and good women accomplishing the seventh dharma among the eighteen dharmas.
Furthermore, good men and good women,

Whether there is form or no form, whether there is sound or no sound, discerning all of it as nonexistent, this is called the good men and good women accomplishing the eighth dharma among the eighteen dharmas.
Furthermore, good men and good women!

Knowing the four noble truths and the eighteen kinds of emptiness that arise from the seven contemplations, this is called the good men and good women accomplishing the ninth dharma among the eighteen dharmas.
Furthermore, good men and good women!

Knowing that formless dharmas exist in both arising and non-arising, discerning all of it as nonexistent, this is called the bodhisattvas accomplishing the tenth dharma among the eighteen kinds of wisdom.
Furthermore, good men and good women!

Contemplating immeasurable worlds knowing that some arise and some cease, like a magician seeing reflections in a mirror, this is called the bodhisattvas accomplishing the eleventh dharma among the eighteen kinds of wisdom.
Furthermore, good men and good women!
You should also know the seven fundamental sufferings.
What are the seven?
First, know that this mind does not come from that, and that mind is also not in this;
Second, that suffering mind has no self and no person, and this suffering mind has no self and no person;
Third, the inconceivable worlds of the buddhas, the tathÄgatas, the arhats, the perfectly enlightened ones can all save those beings;
Fourth, if good men and good women contemplate suffering, emptiness, and non-self within themselves, they do not see the body as if reflecting in a mirror;
Fifth, if I receive a form and sever the ten bodies of dharmas, I also do not see the ten bodies originally coming from me;
Sixth, using the Dharma of fearlessness, do not disturb those who receive it, and the minds of those who receive the teaching do not change;

Seventh, contemplating the practice of non-practice, the fundamental practice, the practice of self, future practice, neither existent nor non-existent, neither non-existent nor not non-existent - this is called the seven practices of suffering;
These are called the bodhisattva's accomplishment of twelve dharmas in the eighteen kinds of wisdom.
Furthermore, good men and good women!
Contemplate immeasurable emptiness, in immeasurable empty thoughts, do not give rise to self-thought nor see that thought.
Why is it so?
Because immeasurable worlds are empty and signless.
This is called the bodhisattva's accomplishment of thirteen dharmas in the eighteen kinds of wisdom.
Furthermore, good men and good women!
You should further contemplate the four immeasurable sufferings.
What are the four sufferings?
In JambudvÄ«pa, contemplate the original causes of immeasurable sentient beings' sufferings:
First, the suffering of birth, knowing the beginning and end of birth, always thinking of the difficulties of the womb;
Second, the suffering of old age, the change in appearance and color, the waning of youthful vigor;

Third, the suffering of illness - when one great element increases, one illness increases; when the four great elements increase, four illnesses increase; when one great element decreases, one illness decreases; when the four great elements decrease, four illnesses decrease.
How is it so?
Son of a great clan!
Are illnesses produced and extinguished, or are they not produced and extinguished?
At that time, a bodhisattva named Original Extinction addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
The four great elements are originally extinguished, not produced and extinguished.
The Buddha said:
Son of a great clan!
How are the four great elements originally extinguished, not produced and extinguished?
He replied:
Originally there were no four great elements. They are born now, not originally existent. Therefore, they are originally extinguished, not produced and extinguished.
The Buddha said:
Son of a great clan!ğŸ”½What is original extinction?
What is produced and extinguished?
He replied:
Originally there is no form, originally there is no birth. Not seeing suffering, not seeing non-suffering, this is called original extinction;
As for what is called arising and ceasing, my present mind can cause this mind to lurk and not arise, this is called arising and ceasing.
The Buddha said:
What do you think?
Son of a great clan!
The past mind and the present mind, the past mind is not the present mind, and the present mind is not the past mind, how can the originally ceased and the ceased through arising cease?
He replied:
The original is without cessation, and the arisen is without cessation.
The Buddha said:
Son of a great clan!
How does the originally ceased and the ceased through arising arise?
He replied:
Because of non-arising, there is arising.
At that time, the World-Honored One!
Praised the Bodhisattva of Original Cessation, saying:
Excellent, excellent!
Son of a great clan!
You are able to speak these words boldly in front of the TathÄgata:

'The suffering of death, when one is about to die, abandons the body and receives a body, in the middle one abides, not knowing where one will go in the future or in the past or present, at that time the spirit is frightened, this is called the suffering of death.'
This is called the bodhisattva's accomplishment of fourteen dharmas in the eighteen kinds of wisdom.
Furthermore, son of noble family!
If a man or woman distinguishes the suffering of no-self as empty and not the body, possessing these four practices one can receive the Tathagata's prediction.
What are the four?
Herein, son of noble family!
If a good man or good woman considers self and no-self as neither having form nor formless, and understands there is nothing, this is called no-self.

If a good man or good woman contemplates the realm of dharmas as suffering without a root, saying there is no suffering and also no arising or ceasing, this is called distinguishing suffering as without suffering.

Just as the immeasurable thoughts of sentient beings pervade the realm of space, knowing that these thoughts arise from the fundamental consciousness and are all exhausted in emptiness, this is called emptiness.
What is meant by non-body?

It refers to the self-attainment of the non-body, the discrimination of the self, the view of self and non-self, the hearing of hearing and non-hearing, the non-existence of the view and the non-existence of hearing, this is called the non-body. This is called the bodhisattva's accomplishment of the fifteenth dharma among the eighteen kinds of wisdom-illumination.
Furthermore, son of noble family!

Just as the suchness of the self is the suchness of the buddhas' dharmas, it is not different from the suchness of the buddhas' dharmas. The existence of the buddhas' dharmas and the existence of suchness are also not different. This is called the bodhisattva's accomplishment of the sixteenth dharma among the eighteen kinds of wisdom-illumination.
Furthermore, son of noble family!

If good men and good women, the Tathagata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, in their past vows, know the equal distribution of the three poisons in sentient beings, and do not see the three poisons and the three pure dharmas, this is called the bodhisattva's accomplishment of the seventeenth dharma among the eighteen kinds of wisdom.
Furthermore, son of noble family!

If good men and good women, recollecting the countless kalpas of the past, and also knowing the countless kalpas of the present, and also knowing the countless kalpas of the future, in each of them discerning that they are non-existent, this is called the bodhisattva's accomplishment of the eighteenth dharma among the eighteen kinds of wisdom.

If good men and good women, discerning the eighteen kinds of wisdom, are fearless in the midst of the great assembly, it is like a valiant and mighty king who has jurisdiction over a territory, and all those who submit to him follow the king's teachings without fail.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this. Having attained the teachings of the holy wisdom and been sealed with the Dharma seal, they are then able to fully understand the immeasurable Dharma gates of wisdom.
What are the immeasurable Dharma gates of wisdom?

The buddhas are inconceivable, the buddha-lands are inconceivable, the dharmas are inconceivable, the dharma-nature of the dharmas is inconceivable, the bhiká¹£u saá¹…gha is inconceivable, the Dharma of the saá¹…gha is inconceivable, and the lands of the saá¹…gha are inconceivable.
In this way, there are four more things in the practice of the Dharma.
What are the four?
First, from beginningless time, one has gone through countless eons, always with a single intention, without error.

If there are good sons and good women who uphold the basis of the single practice and know the end and beginning of existence, and know the end and beginning of the buddhas, they will then be able to fully possess the practice of the equal path.
At that time, there was a bodhisattva named Moonlight Illumination who immediately rose from his seat and said to the Buddha,
World-Honored One!
I am now able to speak of the methods of all dharmas that have an end and those that do not have an end.
How can bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, by perfecting the five practices in the four Dharma bases, fully understand the TathÄgata's fundamental [teachings]?
What are the four?
First, being in the world, fully understanding what to accept and reject, discerning the Dharma of the path and the Dharma of the world, this is called accomplishing the first Dharma.

Furthermore, using the concentration of formless appearance, one responds to the various lands, and in those lands, teaching and transforming sentient beings, manifesting the teaching of non-action, this is called the good sons and good women accomplishing the second Dharma.

Furthermore, good sons and good women, in one's own Dharma of the body, not seeing the body oneself, yet able to deliver innumerable sentient beings, never abandoning the Dharma realm of sentient beings, this is called accomplishing the third Dharma.
Furthermore, good sons and good women, discerning the TathÄgata's three Dharma practices and their basis.
What are the three Dharma practices and their basis?
First, when walking, one should know when to go and when to come, and when sitting, one should be mindful and clear-minded without a distracted mind;

Second, when sitting in meditation, if one wishes to sit cross-legged on the meditation seat, one should then let go of all thoughts and with a single intention and a single mind not move one's body, and complete the meditation without error or disturbance;
If one further engages in various wholesome activities, what one creates will surely be accomplished without other thoughts. This is called accomplishing the four dharmas within the three dharmas.

Furthermore, good men and good women, in the past, future, and present, completely know what will be born, what has not yet been born, and what has already been born, and are then able to make the lion's roar and not lose the Dharma of one's original practice. This is called accomplishing the five dharmas.

Furthermore, good men and women, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas should also be aware of the TathÄgata's three practices. The TathÄgata's meditative absorption is not worldly meditation, nor is it the meditative absorption of Å›rÄvakas or pratyekabuddhas, nor is it the meditative absorption of the first, second, up to the tenth grounds.
Why is this?
Other meditative absorptions have limits, but the TathÄgata's meditative absorption is also without limits.
At that time, the World-Honored One told Bodhisattva Moonlight Illumination:
What do you think?
Son of a great clan!
Are they worldly meditative absorption, learning meditative absorption, no-learning meditative absorption, from the first ground up to the tenth ground meditative absorption?
Bodhisattva Moonlight Illumination addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

As I have heard from the TathÄgata, among those matters, all beings in the desire realm, whether men or women, from the initial arousal of the mind up to the attainment of Buddhahood, from the first ground of the path before entering the stage of bodhisattvas, immediately attain the three meditative absorptions:
There is past meditation, future meditation, and present meditation.

Although these good men and good women attain these three meditations, they can only know their own past bodies, future bodies, and present bodies, and are unable to know the past bodies in others' bodies, the future bodies in others' bodies, or the present bodies in others' bodies.
How do these good men and good women know their own past bodies?
At that time, the World-Honored One!
When sitting in meditation, one should contemplate one's body and give rise to the thought of impurity, and then contemplate:
Alas!
This body of mine is subject to destruction.
With a single thought, one only knows impurity, and is unable to know where it goes.
At that time, the good men and good women should further contemplate:

'I now abandon this body and will seek further insight. Just as I now understand that this body is without self, I also understand that external objects are the same, each and every one is without existence.'
This is called being able to contemplate the past and future right within the present body.
Furthermore, good men and good women, having contemplated their own bodies and external objects, should abandon this mind and seek further insight:
'My present body is all discriminated as neither existent nor non-existent.
Are those sentient beings like my body or not?'
They then discriminate the external and internal past body, sighing that this body will soon be destroyed, and give rise to the thought of impurity.
Having given rise to the thought of impurity, they know that the external and internal past body is no different from their own.
If good men and good women abandon the external and internal past body, they should further give rise to contemplation:
'How does this person's internal past mind arise?'
From what cessation do they arise?
He further thought to himself:
For now, let us set aside the external and past mind.
He then contemplated the external and future mind.
Alas!
From where does this body come?
From where does it cease?
This is called the stage of good sons and good women in the bodhisattva stage, who are then able to fully practice the three dhyÄna practices.
The Buddha further asked Moonlight Illumination Bodhisattva:
How does one cultivate the three dhyÄna practices on the stage of learning?
Moonlight Illumination Bodhisattva addressed the Buddha, saying:

If good sons and good women who are already in the stage of faith are called learners, and then wish to advance towards the path they are heading towards, they should go to six quiet places, such as under a tree, a charnel ground, an empty and open place, and then be able to sit cross-legged, contemplate with an upright mind, and wish to fully practice the three dhyÄna practices.
At that time, the good men and good women should contemplate within themselves:
'Contemplate within yourself: from where did your past body originally arise?
And where does it cease to be?
' Contemplate further:
'Alas!
This body originally has nothing that arises and nothing that ceases.'
The good men and good women should then abandon this body and seek further contemplation:
'From where does my present body arise?
And where does it cease to be?
Is it the same for the future body?'
They should then contemplate:
'From where does the future body arise?
And where does it cease to be?'
They should then think:
'This future body also has no arising and no ceasing.'
This is called the good men and good women on the stage of learning perfecting the three contemplations within their own bodies.
How do those on the stage of learning contemplate their own bodies and perfect the three contemplations within the bodies of others?
At that time, the good men and good women, having abandoned this body and observing their own external bodies, contemplate the past body, thinking, 'Where did it originally come from?'
Where did it originally cease to be?'
They then contemplate thus:
'Alas!
Where did the past body of others come from?
Where did it cease to be?'
They further contemplate thus:
'This past body of mine was neither born nor extinguished.'
Having abandoned this, they seek further observation, thinking:
'This past body of mine is neither born nor extinguished.
This future body of mine, where will it be born?
Where will it cease to be?'
They then think thus:
'This future body of mine will neither be born nor extinguished.'
This is called the good men and good women, in the past and future bodies of others, perfecting the three dhyÄnas.
The Buddha told Moonlight Illumination Bodhisattva:
What is meant by the good men and good women of the stage of no-more-learning being endowed with the three dhyÄnas?
Bodhisattva Moonlight Illumination addressed the Buddha, saying:
If good men and good women wish to enter the stage of no outflows and sever the dharmas of no outflows, they should first contemplate and sit in the full lotus position, internally contemplating:
'From where does this internal past body arise?
From where does it cease?'
They should further contemplate:
'This internal past body neither arises nor ceases.'
At that time, the good men and good women of the stage of no-more-learning, having abandoned this contemplation, should further contemplate:

'I have now contemplated the internal past body. I should further contemplate my past body, which is neither seen to cease nor seen to arise, and which has neither eons nor birth and death, nor any realm.'
This is called the good men and good women being endowed with the three dhyÄnas in the stage of no-more-learning.
The World-Honored One then asked Moonlight Illumination Bodhisattva:
How do bodhisattvas on the first ground not exhaust all practices and perfect the three dhyÄnas?
He replied:

By observing the body with the view of no-self, by not losing the practice of mindfulness with the fundamental non-existence of mindfulness, by not receiving sounds and echoes, passing beyond the first bodhisattva ground, and surpassing the three grounds of faith and all dharmas, this is called the good sons and good women perfecting the three dhyÄnas.
The World-Honored One asked Moonlight Illumination Bodhisattva:
How is it?
Son of good family!
Do you not see your own ground and three dhyÄnas?
He replied:
I do not see any realm, therefore I do not speak.
The Buddha said:
Is it without a body?
Is it with a body?
Why do you not speak?
He replied:
It has a body.
The Buddha asked again:
Is the body the Dharma body?
Or is it the body of the four elements?
He replied:
It is the body of my parents.
The Buddha said:
How can you now, with the body of your parents, accomplish the three dhyÄnas?
Bodhisattva Moonlight Illumination said to the Buddha:

As I first sought the TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One, sitting under the king of trees, fearless and without any anxious thoughts, I then contemplated the burning and blazing of the three realms.
I immediately thought to myself:
'How many sentient beings have been liberated by the past buddhas who have entered parinirvÄá¹‡a? How many past srotÄpannas (stream-enterers)?
How many past saká¹›dÄgÄmins (once-returners)?ğŸ”½How many past anÄgÄmins (non-returners)?
How many past arhats?
How many past pratyekabuddhas (solitary realizers)?'
I further thought to myself:
'It is the same in the future.'
This is called a bodhisattva of the first stage perfecting the practice of the first dhyÄna.

As I, a bodhisattva of the first stage, observe the three realms, the basis of the practice of the first stage surpasses the arhats and pratyekabuddhas. This is called a bodhisattva of the first stage accomplishing the second dhyÄna.

If a good man or good woman, in one ground, distinguishes the internal and external, guards the body and the three emptinesses, and expounds the Dharma teachings without error, this is called accomplishing the three meditations within one ground.
The Buddha further asked Moonlight Illumination Bodhisattva:
Why don't you explain the three meditations of the once-returner and the non-returner?
He replied:
If a good man or good woman is already in the stage of seeing, they will think for themselves:
'My past body within is not this body, and my future body within also does not exist. There is no thought of Buddha, no thought of Dharma, and no thought of seeing the body.'
This is called the internal past body being endowed with the three meditations.
How is the internal future body endowed with the three practices?

At that time, the once-returner further observes internally and externally, abandons all afflictions, and focuses the mind on the third dhyÄna ground without forgetting. Although one attains realization and does not destroy the characteristics of oneself, it is still like the characteristics of dharmas themselves, and one's own discrimination of the body of names, the body of phrases, and the body of meanings.

Furthermore, observing externally, countless sentient beings do not give rise to the thought of Buddha, accomplishing the thought of Buddha, equal and non-dual, all causing purity, not seeing coming and going, without near and far. This is called the once-returner's complete attainment of the three dhyÄnas in the future body within.
Next, the good men and good women sit upright and contemplate, attaining the path of non-returner, and then discriminate for themselves:
I am now definitely in the place of realizing the fruition, not destroying the natural characteristics of dharmas, and verifying for myself.
I have already passed one, already passed two, already passed three, no longer coming and going, abiding in birth and death, the mind and intention calm and unmoving.
This is what is meant by a good man or good woman observing the past in their own body, and the same applies to the future.
At that time, the World-Honored One asked Moonlight Illumination Bodhisattva:
Does the one who returns to the abode of the arhat obtain past dharmas?
Or does he not obtain past dharmas?
He replied:
The one who returns to the abode of the arhat obtains past dharmas, but has not yet exhausted past dharmas.

What is meant by obtaining past dharmas but not yet exhausting past dharmas?ğŸ”½That is to say, the body of the one who returns to the abode of the arhat is in the past, while the dharmas are in the future. This is called obtaining past dharmas but not yet exhausting past dharmas.
Moreover, the body of the one who returns to the abode of the arhat is in the future, while the dharmas have already passed. This is also obtaining past dharmas but not yet exhausting past dharmas.

Furthermore, good men and good women, if an anÄgÄmin's body has not yet passed, and his body has not yet appeared in the present, and the Dharma has already passed, and the Dharma has already appeared before him, this is called an anÄgÄmin obtaining past dharmas and not exhausting past dharmas.
The World-Honored One further asked Moonlight Illumination Bodhisattva:
Does a saká¹›d-ÄgÄmin obtain past dharmas and exhaust past dharmas?
He replied:
Although a saká¹›d-ÄgÄmin has a past body, he does not obtain past dharmas and does not exhaust past dharmas.
How does a saká¹›d-ÄgÄmin have a past body, but does not obtain past dharmas and does not exhaust past dharmas?
He replied:

A saká¹›d-ÄgÄmin's past body has already ceased, but his past dharmas have not yet been exhausted. He himself observes that his future dharmas have already passed, and the dharmas are also non-existent.
Like an anÄgÄmin who has no past body but has past dharmas, therefore a saká¹›d-ÄgÄmin is not like this.
It is like a bright mirror reflecting one's face, unlike face to face, therefore the once-returner is not as good.
The consciousness of the non-returner is like pure refined gold, the consciousness of the once-returner is like gold that has not yet been refined, therefore there is a difference.
The Buddha asked again:
What do you think?
Son of a great clan!

As you have said, does the non-returner attain past dharmas and exhaust past dharmas, attain future dharmas and exhaust future dharmas, and has he already accomplished the dharmas that have not yet been accomplished?ğŸ”½He replied:
He replied:ğŸ”½No, it is not so.ğŸ”½
Although the gold has been refined, it has not yet been made into an implement, and can be called gold but not yet have a form.
The Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent!
Son of a great clan!
You have explained this meaning well.
Just as the non-returner has no past dharmas and does not exhaust past dharmas, has no future dharmas and does not exhaust future dharmas.
Now, does the arhat attain past dharmas and exhaust past dharmas?
Do they attain future dharmas and exhaust future dharmas?
He replied:
They attain past dharmas and exhaust past dharmas, they attain future dharmas and exhaust future dharmas. Therefore, there is a distinction.
At that time, the World-Honored One asked Moonlight Illumination Bodhisattva:
How do bodhisattvas of the second ground perfect the three dhyÄna practices?
He replied:

It is like bodhisattvas of the second ground who give rise to unsurpassed, true, and equal perfect enlightenment. They do not see the inner body and do not see the outer body. They focus their thoughts in front and then contemplate:
'Do I now have an inner past body in my inner body?
Do I not have an inner past body?
Do I have an inner future body?
Do I not have an inner future body?'
After abandoning this contemplation, they further contemplate:
'I now have no inner body and no outer body. How can I seek an inner past body and seek an inner future body in my inner body?'
This is called the second ground bodhisattva being fully endowed with the three dhyÄnas in their own inner and outer body.
At that time, the second ground bodhisattva further thinks like this:
I now fully discern the inner and outer body, and I should next contemplate whether the inner and outer dharmas of others are different from mine.
Turning to advance, I contemplate whether others have a past body or not,
whether they have a future body or not.
This good man or good woman on the second ground, in contemplating others' past bodies, sees no past bodies in others, and in contemplating others' future bodies, sees no future bodies in others.
This is called the second ground good man or good woman fully accomplishing the three dhyÄnas in others' past bodies.
The World-Honored One further asked Moonlight Illumination Bodhisattva:
How do the good men and good women on the third ground accomplish the three dhyÄnas within the third ground?
He replied:
If the good men and good women of the three stages sit upright and contemplate:
'Contemplating the past body within, is there a past body?
Or is there no past body?
Contemplating the future body within, is there a future body?
Or is there no future body?'
They further contemplate:

'I have no past body within the first stage, nor a non-past body. I also have no future body within the first stage, nor a non-future body. I also have no past body of others within the first stage, nor a non-past body. I also have no future body of others within the first stage, nor a non-future body.'
They further contemplate the past body within the second stage, is there a past body?
Or is there no past body?
Contemplating the future body within, is there a future body?
Or is there no future body?
They further contemplate:

'I have no past body within the two lands, nor a non-past body. I also have no future body within the two lands, nor a non-future body. I also have no past body of others within the two lands, nor a non-past body. I also have no future body of others within the two lands, nor a non-future body.
As I now contemplate, within my three lands, the past body within is without a past body within.

I also contemplate the future body within as without a future body within. I contemplate the past body of others within the lands as without a past body of others within. I contemplate the future body of others as without a future body of others. How much less do I have a body or no body?'
This is called the good men and good women perfecting the three meditations within the three lands.
At that time, the World-Honored One asked Moonlight Illumination Bodhisattva:
How do the good men and good women perfect the three meditations within the four lands?
He replied:
If good men and good women of the fourth ground sit upright and contemplate:
'Contemplating internally the past body, is there a past body?
Or is there no past body?
Contemplating internally the future body, is there a future body?
Or is there no future body?'
And further contemplate:
'I have no first ground, second ground, or third ground past body, nor future body, let alone a fourth ground internal past body.
The fourth ground internally has no past body, the fourth ground internally future body, the fourth ground internally has no future body.'
This is called the good men and good women accomplishing the three concentrations within the fourth ground.
At that time, the World-Honored One asked Moonlight Illumination Bodhisattva:
How do the good men and good women of the fifth ground perfect the three concentrations within the fifth ground?
He replied:
If good men and good women of the fifth ground sit upright and contemplate,
contemplating internally the past body, is there a past body?
Is there no past body?
Contemplating internally the future body, is there a future body?
Is there no future body?
They further contemplate:

I have now abandoned the first, second, up to the fourth grounds. Within the four grounds, I internally contemplate the past body with no past body, and internally contemplate the future body with no future body.

Having abandoned this, I contemplate the internal past body of others with no past body, and contemplate the internal future body of others with no future body, let alone whether I have a past body or no past body within the five grounds.
Contemplating the future body of others with no future body.
This is called the good men and good women perfecting the three concentrations within the five grounds.
The World-Honored One further asked Moonlight Illumination Bodhisattva:
How do good men and women of the six grounds perfect the three meditations within the six grounds?
He replied:
If good men and women of the six grounds sit upright and contemplate:
'Contemplating that I have no body, within this body without self, is there a past body?
Is there no past body?
Contemplating within the future body, is there a future body?
Is there no future body?'
This is called good men and women of the six grounds accomplishing the three meditations within the six grounds.
Good men and women of the six grounds, having abandoned the body without self, within others, is there a past body?
Is there no past body?
Within others, is there a future body?
Is there no future body?
They further contemplate:
'Within others, contemplating the past body, there is no past body. Within others, contemplating the future body, there is no future body.'
This is what is meant by good sons and good women accomplishing the three meditations in the six grounds.
The Buddha further asked Moonlight Illumination Bodhisattva:
Good sons and good women in the seven grounds, how do they accomplish the three meditations in the seven grounds?
He replied:
If good sons and good women, in a secluded place, sit upright and contemplate:
Observing the past body within, is there a past body?
Is there no past body?
Again, observing the future body within, is there a future body?
Is there no future body?
Good sons and good women further think like this:

'I have now abandoned the past body within one ground, there is no past body, the future body within is also without a future body, up to the past body within the six grounds, there is no past body within, the future body within is also without a future body.'
How can there be an internal past body and no internal past body in the seven grounds?
How can there be an internal future body and no internal future body?
This is called the accomplishment of the three dhyÄnas by good sons and good women in the seven grounds.
The Buddha further asked Moonlight Illumination:
How do good sons and good women in the seven grounds contemplate the internal past body and non-past body of others?
How do they contemplate the internal future body and non-future body of others?
He replied:

Good sons and good women contemplate the internal past body of others as not having an internal past body of others, and contemplate the internal future body of others as not having an internal future body of others.
The Buddha said:
Stop, stop!
Son of a great clan!
This is not your realm.
Why is it so?
Good men and good women in the seventh ground observe that others' internal past bodies also do not exist, and there are only no others' internal future bodies.
Why do you say that good men and good women in the seventh ground accomplish others' internal future bodies?
Bodhisattva Moonlight Illumination again addressed the Buddha, saying:
As I observe others' internal future bodies, they are neither existent nor nonexistent. Therefore, I say they are accomplished.
The Buddha again asked Bodhisattva Moonlight Illumination:
How do good men and good women in the eighth ground accomplish the three meditations in the eighth ground?
He replied:
If good men and good women sit upright and contemplate:

'Observing one's own internal past body, there is no internal past body. Observing one's own internal future body, there is no internal future body. Observing others' internal past bodies, there are no internal past bodies. Observing others' internal future bodies, there are no internal future bodies.'

Sometimes, good men and good women contemplate their own past bodies as neither existent nor nonexistent, like empty space, but are unable to eliminate their own future bodies;ğŸ”½sometimes, when contemplating their own future bodies, they are unable to eliminate their own past bodies;
sometimes, when contemplating the past bodies of others, they are unable to eliminate the future bodies of others;
when contemplating the future bodies of others, they are unable to eliminate the past bodies of others.
This is called the good men and good women accomplishing the three meditations within the eight grounds.
The Buddha further asked Moonlight Illumination Bodhisattva:
How do the good men and good women of the ninth ground accomplish the three meditations within the ninth ground?
He replied:
If good men and good women sit upright and contemplate:
'Do I have a past body within?
Do I not have a past body?
Contemplating my own future body, do I have a future body?
Is there no future body?'
The good men and good women, having abandoned this contemplation, further contemplate the past body of others, is there a past body?
Is there no past body?
Contemplating the future body of others, is there a future body?
Is there no future body?
Having abandoned this contemplation, they further think like this:
'I originally had no past body, no past body, I originally had no future body, no future body, how much less could there be others' past body, no past body?
Others' future body, no future body, the mind grasping firmly does not abandon the original vow.'
This is called the good men and good women accomplishing the three meditations within the nine grounds.
Furthermore, the good men and good women of the nine grounds should further cultivate the three meditation practices to the seat of enlightenment, without losing them.
What are the three?
First, contemplation;
Second, practice;
Third, basis.
If one accomplishes the three dhyÄnas, one will be able to fully attain the Way.
What is meant by contemplation?
Distinguishing the Dharma realm, knowing the fundamental adornments of various characteristics, this is called contemplation.
What is meant by practice?

Approaching the Bodhi tree, manifesting the form and characteristics of the body, the defilements are already exhausted, not tainted by dust and defilements, the four impermanent dharmas that are always practiced by the Buddhas and TathÄgatas, this is called practice.
What is meant by basis?
The Bodhisattva-mahÄsattva thinks to himself:
I now have fulfilled my great vows and will enable sentient beings to fulfill these great vows.
This is called the basis.
Good men and good women who possess these three practices will be able to fully attain the Way.
Furthermore, good men and good women!
You should also possess three dhyÄnas to attain the Way.
What are the three?
First, emptiness of emptiness;
Second, empty thoughts;
Third, empty consciousness.
If one possesses these three kinds of emptiness, one will be able to fully attain the stage of enlightenment.
What is meant by emptiness of emptiness?

The so-called emptiness refers to observing the emptiness of internal phenomena and the emptiness of external phenomena, observing one world, two worlds, up to countless asaá¹ƒkhyeya worlds, this is called the Dharma of emptiness.
What is meant by empty thoughts?
One then enters concentration and fully observes the world, without giving rise to thoughts of emptiness or non-emptiness, self or non-self, this is called empty thoughts.
What is meant by empty consciousness?
When entering concentration, one further contemplates:
I now have thoughts of sentient beings without any other thoughts. I should purify sentient beings as if they were no different from me.
However, these sentient beings have innumerable consciousnesses. With which consciousness should I transform those many consciousnesses?
I will now use empty consciousness to make this world completely like emptiness, causing those sentient beings to discriminate and become attached to consciousness.'
This is what the good sons and good women possess these three meditations in the nine grounds.
There are three dharmas that can be practiced.
What are the three?
First, discriminating the world;
second, discriminating the realm of sentient beings;
third, discriminating the ultimate truth.
If one cultivates these three dharmas, one will be able to advance to the bodhimanda without fear.
What is meant by discriminating the world?
Completely observing all realms, whether pure or impure, understanding them all without error, and freely selecting and cultivating the buddha-land - this is what is meant by the world.
What is meant by the realm of sentient beings?

They should also universally contemplate all sentient beings, always using skillful means to teach and transform them, not abandoning the vast and great mind of great vows, and going through eons without considering it difficult.
This is called the good men and good women accomplishing the realm of sentient beings.
What is accomplishing the ultimate truth?

Individually discerning the meaning and purport of sentient beings all return to emptiness, without self, person, life, or even one or two, up to all dharmas being also like this. This is called individually discerning the ultimate truth.
If good men and good women accomplish these three dharmas, they will be able to fully progress to the bodhimanda.
There are also three kinds of supernormal powers.
What are the three?
First, the supernormal power of knowing past dharmas;
second, the supernormal power of knowing future dharmas;
third, the supernormal power of knowing present dharmas.
If good men and good women possess these three dharmas, they will be able to fully attain the bodhimanda.
How do the spiritual powers know past phenomena?

In this, good men and good women of the nine grounds know past phenomena as being like the concept of empty space. They discern past sentient beings with defiled minds of desire, anger, and delusion, and with undefiled minds without desire, anger, and delusion. They discern each individually without attachment. This is called the spiritual power of knowing past phenomena.
How do the spiritual powers know future phenomena?

In this, good men and good women of the nine grounds know future sentient beings who will take form, those with defiled minds of desire, anger, and delusion, and those with undefiled minds without desire, anger, and delusion. They discern each individually without attachment. This is called the spiritual power of knowing future phenomena.

Furthermore, the good men and good women of the ninth ground know the minds of all sentient beings in the present that are defiled by desire, anger, and delusion, and those that are undefiled by desire, anger, and delusion. They discern each one without attachment. This is called the supernormal knowledge of knowing the present dharmas.
This is called the accomplishment of the three dharmas that progress to the site of enlightenment of the ninth ground.
Furthermore, the good men and good women of the ninth ground have three more dharmas that enable them to reach the site of enlightenment.
What are the three?
First, purity of body;
second, purity of speech;
third, purity of mind.
Endowed with these three dharmas, one can reach the site of enlightenment.
What is meant by purity of body?

The body has already transcended innumerable virtues and practices. The original practices have ceased and one does not create bodily actions again. The body penetrates through without obstruction. This is called the purity of body of the bodhisattva of the ninth ground.
What is meant by purity of speech?
It produces innumerable teachings.
Never damaging the profound and wondrous treasury, this is called purity of speech.
What is purity of mind?
Removing attachment and not accepting defilements, this is called purity of mind.
At that time, Bodhisattva Moonlight Illumination spoke this verse:
The body is pure, without flaws or impurities, neither inside nor outside is there anything to be attached to,
Virtuous and lofty, without equal, forever extinguishing desire, anger, and pride.
The mouth is pure, expounding all teachings, without leaking any faults,
Until attaining nirvana, the teachings of the mouth are inexhaustible.
The mind is pure, removing greed and attachment, with compassion and pity, without increase or decrease,
Receiving birth in immeasurable realms, awakening those who are not yet awakened.
Beyond the nine grounds and the Dharma realm, neither existent nor nonexistent,
These good men have already entered the realm of the Tathagata.
I, for countless eons, diligently studied and pursued teachers and companions,
Because they have not yet practiced this, how much less so those who fall into other [paths]?
Upholding practice without attachment, accumulating one thing and attaining Buddhahood,
Practice surpasses the three realms, the lion's roar among humans.
This is called the nine grounds. Good men and good women accomplish three dharmas.
